awd_titl_txt: Conference: Global Bioinformatics Education Summit 2024 — Energizing Communities to Power the Bioeconomy Workforce
awd_abstract_narration:
The 6th Global Bioinformatics Education Summit will take place in New York City, to address the challenges of fostering a data-literate life sciences workforce. The Summit will feature world leaders in education policy and practice, and will include sessions focused on how policymakers, funders and industry partners can work together to create national strategies that support bioinformatics education and training. Bioinformatics-skilled individuals are critical to meet 21st century US needs for a changing workforce active in the bioeconomy. 

Scientific progress in biology is increasingly data-rich and model-driven, requiring skills currently outside of the standard biology curriculum. Data science programs alone cannot supply the need because domain-specific knowledge is essential for deriving understanding from information. Summit activities are focused on supporting working groups tasked with creating and sustaining the development of products such as curricula, competency frameworks, roadmaps and policy papers. A broad range of participants will be recruited, in order to ensure that perspectives from many affected groups are incorporated in the planning documents. The long-term goal is to create a comprehensive, broadly available, inclusive and actionable bioinformatics education strategy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Global Bioinformatics Education Summit (GBES) 2024, held at the New York Genome Center, addressed critical challenges in bioinformatics education, aiming to build a data-literate life sciences workforce and strengthen the bioeconomy. The Summit brought together 270 participants (70 in person and 200 virtual) from over 50 countries, fostering a global network of educators, industry leaders, funders, and policymakers. A major highlight was the inaugural Funders, Industry, and Policymakers Forum, which promoted the development of a U.S. national bioinformatics education strategy as a cornerstone for driving innovation and competitiveness in the bioeconomy.

Survey results underscored the Summit’s success. Among attendees, 86% reported gaining access to new resources, materials, and approaches in bioinformatics education, 79% established valuable professional connections, and 70% improved their ability to deliver impactful training and education. Notably, 100% of attendees expressed interest in participating in future Summits, highlighting the positive impact on the community.

The intellectual merit of the Summit centered on realizing the unique role of bioinformatics educators play as a distinct subset of data scientists critical to all areas of life sciences research. By equipping educators with cutting-edge tools, methodologies, and networking opportunities, the event directly supports the advancement of bioinformatics—a discipline essential for analyzing complex biological data and driving discoveries in genomics, healthcare, agriculture, and beyond. These advancements are fundamental to strengthening the bioeconomy, as bioinformatics innovations underlie the development of new therapeutics, sustainable agricultural practices, and environmental solutions.

The Funders, Industry, and Policymakers Forum further amplified the Summit’s broader impacts by aligning key stakeholders around a shared vision for bioinformatics education. Representatives from leading organizations such as the NSF, NIH, and the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative discussed strategies to create sustainable, national-scale solutions for bioinformatics training. This dialogue highlighted the importance of a coordinated U.S. bioinformatics education strategy as a strategic opportunity to fuel the bioeconomy, ensuring a well-prepared workforce to meet the growing demands of data-driven life sciences research.

Through its global approach, international collaboration, and emphasis on actionable outcomes, the GBES 2024 not only strengthened the bioinformatics education community but also laid the groundwork for sustainable growth in the field. By empowering educators and aligning stakeholders, GBES 2024 contributed to building a robust, diverse, and globally connected bioinformatics education ecosystem that supports advancements across all life sciences and strengthens the bioeconomy.


Last Modified: 01/28/2025
Modified by: Jason J Williams
